title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineJust  weeks’ notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region’s elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country – have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor’s owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care – but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don’t have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure – with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke – but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete – andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual’s home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newsthe people you are visiting may be particularly vulnerable
story: The public has been urged to keep wearing face coverings when visiting hospitals, care homes and other health and care settings. The appeal from the Chief Medical Officer comes with reports of a decline in wearing of face coverings by visitors. Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “The COVID- Omicron iant is extremely infectious and, despite best efforts, can spread quickly in health and social care settings. “Please remember to wear a face covering when you are visiting. The people you are coming to see may be particularly vulnerable to the virus - as may other patients or residents. “Also, do not visityou have symptoms of respiratory infection.” The Chief Medical Officer added: “Wearing a face covering remains an important way to protect others, as well as yourself. Public health advice continues to encourage their use in everyday le. That also includes on public transport and in any indoor busy setting - especiallythey are not well ventilated.”

title: education minister visits ballymena primary school
story: EDUCATION Minister Michelle McIlveen paid a recent visit to Ballymena Primary School.During the visit on March  the Minister spoke to members of the student bodies active within the school which included the School Council, Eco-Council and Digital Leaders. She witnessed children engaging in ICTlessons, in play sessions both indoor and outdoor and spoke extensively to staff on the Special Needs team. The pastoral and Mental Health programmes within the school were of interest to Minister McIlveen as well as how children had found theto face-to-face learning after Lockdowns. The Minister also enjoyed seeing a class making toast around the fire pit as part of their Forest School activities and was shown the continual development in children’s outdoor learning in the school which the staff were finding to have had a positive impact upon their well-being and academic achievement.The Minister was initially due to visit Ballymena Primary School as part of their ceremony to celebrate an outdoor play award called TOPS back in October . Due to ious Assembly commitments the Minister had been unable to visit until now and was keen to honour a promise made to visit what was the first primary school of the town established back in . Minister McIlveen was pleasantly surprised by the extensive, bright and modern interior of the school which was not immediately evident from outside and complimented the children on their behaviour, enthusiasm and sense of responsibility. The children of the school were happy to welcome Minister McIlveen and staff were delighted to be able to share some of the developments and progress made within the school due to the hard work and dedication of the staff.Principal, Mrs Ritchie said: “We were so pleased to welcome the Education Minister to Ballymena Primary School on Wednesday as a way of celebrating all of the continued hard work and advances within the school. “The Minister was happy to engage with the children and staff and asked interested questions around child development and we were keen to display as many aspects of our educational provision as time would allow.”

title: daria through to miss ni final
story: A former pupil of Patricks College in Ballymena has made it through to the final of the Miss Northern Ireland competition.Daria Gapska, a -year-old childrens nursing student, recently ed to the college for a presentation to Year  on her chosen charity Braveheartsni.Daria was one of two finalists to be crowned at the first live Miss World Northern Ireland Heat of  in Nu Delhi, Belfast in front of an an astute judging  which included Managing Director of ACA models and Event organiser Victoria Withers. The event saw girls from across Northern Ireland compete for their place at the Miss World Northern Ireland final.Daria was crowned as Miss Nu Delhi and Poppy Smith a  year old Biomedical Science student from Portadown was crowned as Miss Belfast. St Patricks College congratulated their former pupil on her success in the competition.The school said: “Daria has chosen Braveheartsni as her charity. It is a charity very close to our hearts as founder, Shealyn Caulfield is also a past pupil. “Daria did an excellent presentation on the charity to our Year  pupils and will present this to other Year Groups next week.“We wish her all the best with her preparations for the Miss Northern Ireland final.”Braveheartsni is Northern Ireland’s only charity supporting the needs of teenagers and young adults with Adult Congenital Heart Disease.The charity has grown from the strong volunteer ethos of HeartbeatNI who are also a local volunteer charity who support families with children with congenital heart disease.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newscurry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. Happy days.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newsfamiliar faces on this week s rare breed
story: UTV’s hit farming series, ‘Rare Breed - A Farming Year’, s on Tuesday th April at pm. The families are bringing in their ious harvests and making preparations for next year. It’s October, and on the shores of Strangford Lough the Elliott family rear turkeys. The family have years of experience looking after the birds and yet Mark and Olive are still fascinated by their behaviour. Olive comments that they are ‘extremely inquisitive’. While Mark is making sure the turkeys are well fed, his mum Olive can’t help giving them an extra treat. She comments too, “I can’t do without my family, I have to be so nice to them at the minute!” Mark points out that they have been receiving orders for Christmas since August, which is ‘absolutely nuts.’ Near Kilcoo in the Mourne Mountains, Aine Devlin is preparing her flock for the most critical part of her farming year- breeding season. Aine is keeping an eye on her rams to make sure they’re doing their job. She coats their chests with paint to see which ewes they have been with. Aine laughs, “This is his cologne for the girls!” For her AI is not the way to go as the ewes would then all lamb on the same day on the mountain. She loves this time of year and is proud of the part she plays in the economy. “What’s better than buying produce from down the road from your neighbours and local communities ” she says. Outside Crossgar, Richard Orr is thinking ahead to next year’s wheat crop. It’s all about the planning and attention to detail to make sure the groundwork is done right. He’s conscious of the environment, saying, “The major thing in the world is carbon footprint. Chemicals have made farming easy, and modern machinery has damaged the structure of the soil - we need to rebuild that.” Meanwhile, just outside Portadown it’s all hands on deck for apple harvest at the McKeever family farm. There isn’t a high yield this year but sometimes things not going to plan can be a blessing. Pat talks about the seven to eight weeks of hell and this year pickers have been hard to get. Peter comments, “It’s half the battle when you have good people around.” On the Donegal   Londonderry border, potato farmer Jamie Rankin and his team are coming towards the end of their harvest. He enjoys the early starts and says, “What you do before dinner time’s your day’s work.” While it’s a job Jamie enjoys, it also comes with challenges as winter months close in. The bad weather has led to reduced yields and a late harvest, but he’s very proud to have produced a good crop. UTV’s Mark McFadden narrates the series. Sponsored by Moy Park, ‘Rare Breed – A Farming Year’ continues on Tuesday th April at pm on UTV.

title: calls for an update on school transport ahead of proposed strike action by bus drivers
story: The Translink pay dispute affects bus drivers, cleaners and shuntersKellie Armstrong. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Translink pay dispute affects bus drivers, cleaners and shuntersGarrett HarganTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Education Minister and Education Authorityneed to urgently update parents on how pupils will be transported to schools ahead of a strike beginning later this month, Alliance’s Kellie Armstrong has said.Strangford Assembly candidate Ms Armstrong was speaking ahead of a strike by bus drivers, scheduled to begin on April .She said the issue had been raised by concerned parents during the election campaign.“Alliance believes in the right of workers to strike, however there are consequences which need to be thought about,” Ms Armstrong said.“The Education Minister and EA have been aware of the upcoming strike for some time, yet have not provided parents with solutions should Translink be unable to provide home to school transport for those in receipt of it.“This issue has been raised a number of times by concerned parents on the doors during this election campaign. They need to know arrangements as soon as possible, as otherwise they will have to source childcare or take holidays from their own place of work.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreNorthern Ireland bus network risks ‘complete shutdown’ as Translink workers vote for strike action, union warnsIf a number of buses do not operate later this month due to the strike, she questioned whether pupils will be treated as absentthey can’t attend. Ms Armstrong added: Will there be any consideration given relating to lost learning timethey are due to sit exams soon “There has so far been silence from Minister Michelle McIlveen and the EA, which is incredibly disappointing for parents across Northern Ireland.With a potential strike by classroom assistants possibly happening after Easter as well, it is vital things are not left until the last minute.We need more communication and for the Minister and EA to show they care about the safety of our children and young people, and having their access to education disrupted as Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumDerry one of best places to live in Northern Ireland: A rich history, friendly people, and proud music and sporting traditions make city a fantastic place to liveGarrett HarganExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDerry City Walls FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDerry City WallsApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDerry has rightly been recognised as one of the best places to live in Northern Ireland given the city’s welcoming atmosphere and history.The Sunday Times took account of a wide range of factors — from schools, transport and broadband to culture, green spaces and the health of the high street.The Best Places to Live list celebrates improving towns, villages or city centres, attractive, well-designed homes and locations bursting with community spirit.What makes Derry a great place to live is its rich history and people who are both warm and friendly with a sense of comradery.That is not conjecture or bias from a local, but is borne out in polls where the city sits at the top for being the most generous in the UK for donations on pages such as GoFundMe.The city is believed to have been founded by Saint Columba in AD . That means there is much for visitors to explore, from ancient to modern history.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to live in : Proud locals are in full agreement as Co Antrim town edges out Derry and Helen’s Bay‘There’s no place like home’: Derry Girls writer Lisa McGee reacts to city being named among top places to live in NIYou have the completely intact -year-old Derry Walls which is a real selling point for tourists.Other historic landmarks include the Guildhall — where it now stands was once the middle of the River Foyle where ships moored. It was mostly destroyed by fire in  and after extensive rebuilding was opened in .Because it is relatively small in size, Derry is an easy place to navigate for visitors.A key piece of infrastructure built in recent times was the Peace Bridge.Nowadays it is hard to imagine the city without it, and it’s an area of recreation popular with walkers and joggers.That area is arguably the best feature of the city, expanding the city centre, linking to Ebrington, St Columb’s Park and the renovated railway station.The Peace Bridge connects the Cityside and Waterside it was a masterstroke both in practical terms and as an act of symbolism by reconnecting the largely Catholic Cityside to the traditionally unionist Waterside. Derry is also a city of culture — made official in  — with musicians, poets, painters and actors famous the world over.Danny Boy is one of the most famous songs in the world, and has been covered by Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Eva Cassidy. Phil Coulter, The Undertones, Dana, Cara Dillon, Johnny McDaid of Snow Patrol fame, Red Organ Serpent Sound, Fighting with Wire, SOAK and Wood Burning Savages show the range of musicians Derry has produced.It is also a city with proud sporting traditions in GAA and football and has produced Olympic medallists and world champions who first learned their trade on Derry’s pitches, roads and rivers.Nowhere does a festival like Derry, but there should be more added to the calendar.You have Glasgowbury in Draperstown, the City of Derry Jazz and Big Band Festival, the legendary Halloween festival and, in recent times, the Foyle Maritime Festival, which have all proven popular.When considering Derry, you also have to factor in the location. A short drive across the border and you’re in some of the world’s nicest beaches including Dunree and Tullagh Bay.To Derry’s advantage in the Sunday Times survey was an average house price of £,.“Reaping the rewards of years of investment and with a fine cultural reputation, this much-improved city stands out as somewhere cool, credible and cheap, with a bright future,” The Sunday Times states.But most people in the city would disagree with that statement, as multiple-deprivation measures, unemployment rates and analysis of investment show the second city has not received a great deal of inward investment.For example, since Invest NI was formed in  until   it has assisted , new jobs in Belfast whereas Foyle got , and East Londonderry ,.In that time it invested £.bn in Belfast and £.bn between Foyle and East Londonderry.Most ReadVideo: Feral teenagers’ attack on police in Co Down village caught on cameraBelfast paedophile brothers Gary and Gregory Rea shocked to be shunned title: new belfast transport hub to be named belfast grand central station
story: Artist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArtist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast’s new transport hub will be officially named Belfast Grand Central Station, Translink has confirmed.Work on the south Belfast station began in February and is expected to open by . The major infrastructural scheme led by Northern Ireland’s public transport provider stretches across , sqft, replacing the existing Europa and Great Victoria Street bus and rail stations. When completed, it will become the largest integrated transport hub on the island of Ireland.The hub will provide  bus stands, eight railway s and an enhanced walking and cycling connectivity across the city.When the £m project was announced in , Translink said the project would create  new jobs.Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon, who visited the project’s building site earlier this year, described it as “exciting” and said it will be a “game changer” for Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “I have been clear that we need to see an increase in the use of public transport and encourage more people to consider active travel options so that we can tackle the climate crisis,” she said.“To achieve that we need to have the right infrastructure in place.”Another project running alongside the Transport Hub at Weavers Cross close to Sandy Row will also regenerate the .m square foot brownfield site in the area.Ms Mallon added: “With an expected annual footfall of over  million, this important NI Executive flagship project will bring a host of benefits to support the economy.“It will improve connectivity for everyone in Northern Ireland and beyond, and will be a key driver of social, economic and environmental wellbeing for the local and wider community.On Thursday, Translink tweeted that the new Grand Central is being “celebrated with community engagement, through an innovative ‘It’s Grand’ Story Board at Europa Bus Centre”. The new station is also only a stone’s throw away from the Hastings-owned Grand Central Hotel, which opened on Bedford Street in .The name itself is full of history, as the city’s first Grand Central Hotel was opened on Royal Avenue in June  by Downpatrick man John Robb.He had originally planned to develop a huge central railway terminus on the site – based on New York#s famous Grand Central Station – but failed to get support from local politicians at the time.It closed its doors in  when the Troubles broke out and was later taken over by the Army in  for use as a base, eventually being demolished in the late s. The site is now home to the Castle Court shopping centre.The train station formerly known as Belfast Central, which is located on Bridge Street in the Laganside area of the city, was renamed Lanyon Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium NI Civil Service chief apologises to senior whistleblower vet hounded out of jobExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDr Tamara Bronckaers FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr Tamara BronckaersSam McBrideTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe head of the Northern Ireland Civil Service has issued an “unreserved apology” to a civil servant hounded out of her job because she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering and attempted to enforce the law.On Thursday, the Belfastrevealed that the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairshas abandoned its attempt to overturn a devastating industrial tribunal judgment that a senior vet in his department, Tamara Bronckaers, was effectively sacked — and was treated appallingly by one of Stormont’s most senior officials who remains in post.Seven months ago, an industrial tribunal unanimously found that Tamara Bronckaers, a senior vet at DAERA with an “exemplary performance and record”, had been effectively sacked because she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering.However, rather than accept a verdict which was devastating for the credibility of Northern Ireland’s chief vet, Robert Huey, and the department, DAERA instead appealed the verdict to the Court of Appeal — a highly unusual decision, which would only succeedthe judge who heard the case had made major errors.Read MoreStormont department apologises and drops its legal challenge over whistleblowerBut last week the department suddenly U-turned to abandon its protracted and expensive fight which taxpayers have funded and is likely to cost well over £ million. DAERA instead struck a deal with Dr Bronckaers which will involve the department admitting that the original judgment was right, and paying her a huge sum in compensation.That judgment repeatedly criticised the whistleblower’s treatment by two of her senior colleagues: line manager Julian Henderson and chief vet Robert Huey. DAERA has taken no action against either man.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the heart of the case was Dr Bronckaers’ desire to enforce the law against Ballymena Livestock Market over alleged suffering caused to animals, as well as livestock movements being electronically deleted from DAERA’s much-vaunted computer system meant to track all inter-farm moves to ensure traceability of meat.Dr Huey told Dr Bronckaers that he knew the manager of Ballymena Livestock Market personally and that he also knew its chairman. Both he and Dr Henderson discouraged her from pursuing enforcement of the law, with Dr Bronckaers left in tears after an encounter with Dr Huey.In a statement on Thursday, DAERA said it “unreservedly apologises” to Dr Bronckaers and said it had set up an “internal review” into the issue. The department also denied that Minister Edwin Poots had ever had any involvement in the case, despite being in charge of the department and despite the case having been extensively reported by this newspaper and other media outlets for months.Last month the Belfastasked the Head of the Civil Service, Jayne Brady,it was acceptable on her watch for a Stormont department to attempt to overturn a judicial finding that a civil servant was driven from her job after she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering, and whether she had any message for whistleblowers. At the time, Dr Brady said it was “not appropriate to comment on an ongoing legal issue which is a matter for DAERA”.However, now that DAERA has abandoned its appeal, Dr Brady has issued her first substantive comment on the case. In a brief statement to this newspaper, a spokesman for Dr Brady said: “As Head of the Civil Service, I unreservedly apologise to Dr Bronckaers.“This case highlights a number of signicant concerns and I welcome the internal audit being undertaken by DAERA into this matter. Work is underway on actions to improve our processes for dealing with concerns raised both internally and externally and I have asked that this is taken forward at pace and consistently across all departments.“This underlines the need to drive forward the important work we have committed to do as an employer.”Related topicsDepartment of Agriculture, Environment  Rural Affairs - Edwin PootsMore title: p and o ferries set to restart larne to cairnryan route following inspection
story: PO at Larne port . FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePO at Larne port .Garrett HarganTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFerry company PO has announced that services between Larne and Cairnryan in Scotland will restart on Sunday morning.Its vessels were grounded last month after PO sacked around  seafaring workers over a Zoom call and replaced them with low-paid agency staff.The company faced widespread criticism from workers and trade unions over the dismissals.A spokesperson for PO Ferries said: “On Friday, the Maritime and Coastguard Agencycompleted its most recent inspection of the European Causeway, and have confirmed it is safe to sail.“We are delighted that we will be able to restart full services between Larne and Cairnryan from am, Sunday th April.“PO is pleased to play its part in supporting customers to move vital goods between the Northern Ireland and Scotland.”On Thursday the Maritime and Coastguard Agencysaid it was carrying out a reinspection of the European Causeway at PO Ferries’ request.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up An MCA spokesman said: “All inspections have to satisfy the Maritime and Coastguard Agency that the ferries fulfil the requirement of the Port State Control regime and are safe to put to sea.“There are no further inspections of PO Ferries at the moment but we will reinspect at the appropriate time.”Earlier this week PO said the Larne route and others would resume this weekend.Rival ferry company Stena Line has been absorbing some of the business from would-be PO customers, on its Belfast to Cairnryan route.One worker said staff at the business were “working their socks off” to cope with the big jump in demand.The business was thought to be meeting between  and % of the demand from PO customers.It had erted one ship, the Nordica, from the Holyhead to Dublin route to service the demand.As well as members of the public, PO also provides services to commercial customers such as Asda and Marks  Spencer.Most ReadVideo: Feral teenagers’ title: what the papers say april
story: What the papers say – April   FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueWhat the papers say – April  By PA ReporterApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailRishi Sunak’s woes, a Covid-exhausted monarch and the French election are splashed across the front pages.The beleaguered Chancellor has referred himself to Boris Johnson’s independent adviser on ministerial interests as he sought to fend off questions over his family’s financial affairs, according to The Daily .The front page of tomorrow#s The Daily :Sunak faces inquiry into his financial interests#TomorrowsPapersToday for our Front Page newsletter https:t.co JIMevXrNiU pic LSJJtmWlT— The April , The i says the move means Mr Sunak’s hopes of becoming Prime Minister “appear to be all but over”.Monday#s front page: Rishi Sunak#s hopes of becoming PM evaporate#TomorrowsPapersToday pic XzuiretcD— i newspaperApril , The Independent reports more than  food banks have warned the Chancellor they are close to “breaking point” due to a signicant surge in demand.Tomorrow#s @independent front page #tomorrowspaperstoday To subscribe to the Daily Edition https:t.co koJcLNax pic qylDFOXW— Thair ShaikhApril , Home Secretary Priti Patel is cited on the front of the Daily Mail as blaming environmental activists for “inflicting fuel shortages on motorists”.Monday’s Daily MAIL: “Priti Blasts ‘Selfish’ Petrol Protests” #TomorrowsPapersToday pic ZLYrQSxdS— Allie Hodgkins-BrownApril , The Queen was left “very tired and exhausted” from suffering Covid-, reports the Daily Mirror and .Tomorrow#s front page - Queen: Covid left me exhausted#tomorrowspaperstodayhttps:t.co EMcfORAbft pic VfwNxarjzZ— The MirrorApril , Monday’s front page:QUEEN: MY COVID FIGHT#tomorrowspaperstoday #BBCPapers #skypapers pic WBLfgxfAnx—Newspaper UKApril , The French election is covered by the Financial Times, The Times and , which say incumbent Emmanuel Macron is set to face far-right rival Marine Le Pen in a run-off for the presidency.Just published: front page of the Financial Times, UK edition, Monday  April https:t.co naIdPYagw pic rTZhDEkn— Financial TimesApril , Monday’s TIMES: “French election in balance after narrow Macron win” #TomorrowsPapersToday pic pmjtHjuMX— Allie Hodgkins-BrownApril ,  front page, Monday  April : Macron and Le Pen face off in fight for France’s future pic hFCInusRo— April , The Sun carries a photograph of a newly married Brooklyn Beckham and his American bride Nicola Peltz in a Jaguar convertible, thought to be a wedding gt from the groom’s father David.On tomorrow#s front page: Brooklyn Beckham takes his bride for a ride in a classic car today- in their first sighting as newlyweds. https:t.co qZKZWZZ pic QcIhKrYks— The SunApril , And the Daily Star looks ahead to warmer weather as it anticipates a “Good Fryday” for those on an Easter staycation.Tomorrow#s front page: Brits to sizzle in C scorcher #tomorrowspaperstodayMore here: https:t.co iBZBlWvgo pic lEQUZfCOg— Daily StarApril ,  Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletter Receive todays headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.
